content.user_title: Skill Development Guide for Claude Code
content.value_statement: Learn to create effective, well-structured skills for Claude Code plugins using progressive disclosure, proper formatting, and best practices.
actual_capabilities: Provides step-by-step process for creating skills from understanding use cases to validation
Explains skill anatomy (SKILL.md, scripts/, references/, assets/) and when to use each component
Teaches progressive disclosure: metadata always loaded, SKILL.md when triggered, resources as needed
Defines writing style requirements (imperative form, third-person descriptions, objective language)
Shows how to write effective trigger phrases in skill descriptions
Explains how to organize content (lean SKILL.md body, detailed content in references/)
Provides validation checklist and common mistakes to avoid
Includes real examples from plugin-dev skills (hook-development, agent-development, etc.)
limitations: Focused specifically on Claude Code plugin skills, not generic skill creation
Does not include init_skill.py script (plugin skills created manually)
No automated packaging process for plugin skills (distributed as part of plugin)
Requires understanding of Claude Code plugin structure

use_cases.title: Creating a New Skill from Scratch
use_cases.description: Developer wants to add a new skill to their Claude Code plugin. Follow 6-step process: understand use cases, plan resources, create structure, edit SKILL.md, validate, iterate.

use_cases.title: Improving Existing Skill Descriptions
use_cases.description: Skill exists but doesn't trigger properly. Learn to write third-person descriptions with specific trigger phrases like "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook".

use_cases.title: Organizing Skill Content with Progressive Disclosure
use_cases.description: SKILL.md is too large (>3,000 words) and bloats context. Learn to keep SKILL.md lean (1,500-2,000 words) and move detailed content to references/.

use_cases.title: Validating Skill Structure
use_cases.description: Before publishing plugin, ensure skill follows best practices: proper frontmatter, imperative writing style, working examples, referenced resources.

prompt_templates.title: Create New Skill
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to create a skill for [specific task]. Users would ask things like "[example query 1]" or "[example query 2]". Can you help me create this skill?
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new skill from scratch

prompt_templates.title: Improve Skill Description
prompt_templates.prompt: My skill description is "[current description]". It's not triggering when users ask about [topic]. Can you help improve it with specific trigger phrases?

prompt_templates.title: Organize Skill Content
prompt_templates.prompt: My SKILL.md is [X] words long with detailed [pattern/API/configuration] information. How should I reorganize this using progressive disclosure?

prompt_templates.title: Validate Skill
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my skill at [path] and check if it follows best practices for description, writing style, and progressive disclosure.

output_examples.input: Help me create a skill for validating JSON configuration files
output_examples.output: Guides through: (1) Understanding use cases: "What JSON formats? What validations?", (2) Planning resources: scripts/validate-json.py for validation, references/schemas.md for JSON schemas, examples/valid-config.json, (3) Creating structure in skills/json-validator/, (4) Writing SKILL.md with triggers like "validate JSON", "check config file", (5) Adding validation script and examples, (6) Testing trigger phrases

output_examples.input: My skill description is 'Provides hook guidance' - why isn't it triggering?
output_examples.output: Identifies issues: (1) Not third-person, (2) No specific trigger phrases, (3) Too vague. Suggests improved description: 'This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook", "validate tool use", or mentions hook events (PreToolUse, PostToolUse, Stop).'

best_practices: Use third-person in frontmatter description: 'This skill should be used when...'
Include specific trigger phrases users would say: "create X", "configure Y", "validate Z"
Keep SKILL.md body lean (1,500-2,000 words), move detailed content to references/
Write in imperative/infinitive form: 'Configure the setting' not 'You should configure'
Create directory structure only for needed resources (references/, examples/, scripts/)
Reference supporting files clearly in SKILL.md so Claude knows they exist
Provide working, complete examples that users can copy and adapt
Study existing plugin-dev skills as templates (hook-development, agent-development)
Validate before publishing: check description quality, writing style, progressive disclosure
Test skill triggers on expected user queries
anti_patterns: Vague descriptions like 'Provides guidance for X' without trigger phrases
Using second person: 'You should do X' instead of imperative 'Do X'
Putting everything in SKILL.md (>3,000 words) instead of using progressive disclosure
Creating empty directories (references/, examples/, scripts/) when not needed
Not referencing supporting files in SKILL.md body
Duplicating information between SKILL.md and references/

faq.question: What's the difference between scripts/, references/, and assets/?
faq.answer: scripts/ contains executable code for deterministic tasks (validation, automation). references/ contains documentation loaded into context as needed (schemas, API docs, patterns). assets/ contains files used in output without loading to context (templates, images, boilerplate).

faq.question: How do I know if my SKILL.md is too long?
faq.answer: Target 1,500-2,000 words for SKILL.md body, max 3,000 words. If longer, move detailed content to references/. Keep only core concepts, essential procedures, and pointers to references in SKILL.md.

faq.question: What makes a good skill description?
faq.answer: Third-person format ('This skill should be used when...'), specific trigger phrases users would say ('create a hook', 'validate JSON'), concrete scenarios, not vague. Example: 'This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a skill", "add a skill to plugin", "write a new skill"...'

faq.question: How does progressive disclosure work?
faq.answer: Three levels: (1) Metadata (name + description) always in context, (2) SKILL.md body loaded when skill triggers, (3) Bundled resources (references, examples, scripts) loaded as needed by Claude. This keeps context lean while making detailed information available.

faq.question: Do plugin skills need to be packaged as ZIP files?
faq.answer: No. Unlike standalone skills, plugin skills are distributed as part of the plugin directory structure. Users get skills automatically when they install the plugin. No separate packaging needed.

faq.question: How do I test if my skill triggers correctly?
faq.answer: Install plugin locally with 'cc --plugin-dir /path/to/plugin', then ask questions using the exact trigger phrases from your description. Verify the skill loads and provides appropriate guidance.
